thread.title: Weak US retail sales put hopes of interest rate hike on ice
thread.title_full: Weak US retail sales put hopes of interest rate hike on ice

title: Weak US retail sales put hopes of interest rate hike on ice
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Wed, Oct 14, 2015, 17:38 BST - UK Markets closed Weak US retail sales put hopes of interest rate hike on ice By Peter Spence | Telegraph – 1 hour 15 minutes ago 0.00 
A rising dollar and weak inflation have hampered US retail sales growth 
Disappointing US retail sales have all but closed the door on a possible interest rate rise this year, as concerns over the health of the world economy have grown. 
Shoppers spent just 0.1pc more in September than August, half the pace of growth expected by analysts. Excluding car sales, total sales fell by 0.3pc compared with the previous month, according to the US Census Bureau . 
Revisions to previous data painted a darker picture of the US economy, with August's 0.4pc rise in sales nudged down to 0.2pc, and July's 0.6pc gain amended to 0.5pc. 
A strengthening dollar and weak inflation have kept the costs of goods low, weighing on retail sales' value growth. Ian Shepherdson of Pantheon Macroeconomics said that, as a result, "slowing sales don’t necessarily imply slowing real consumption", as volumes could still be rising. 
The data come as the US Federal Reserve continues to mull over an interest rate rise, as it weighs the impact of a slowing Chinese economy and inflation that is well below target. 
Minutes of its September rate-setting meeting showed that the central bank was worried that emerging weakness could hit US exports and cause the dollar to appreciate further, reducing growth and inflation. 
Paul Ashworth, chief US economist at Capital Economics, said that the retail figures "support our view that the Fed probably isn't going to hike interest rates until early next year". 
Traders believe that there is just a 30.4pc chance of a Fed rate hike by the end of the year, believing that one will arrive in March instead. The central bank has kept its interest rates close to zero since 2008. 
Capital Economics now believes that US GDP rose by just 0.5pc in the third quarter of the year. 
As a result, the US central bank might hold off on interest rate rises for longer, believing that tighter policy would hinder efforts to get the economy running at full speed. 
James Knightley, an economist at ING, said that analysts would need to see "a very strong labour report next month to give them any confidence the Fed will hike in December". 
Disheartening jobs figures revealed that the US added just 142,000 jobs in September , well below the 201,000 expected by forecasters. The economy would need to generate far more jobs in October to reignite hopes of higher rates (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
